title: Discussion 1 Thread
content: <document version="1.0"><paragraph>Discussion 1 will be held at two times:</paragraph><paragraph>Wednesday at 3-4pm in Social Sciences Building 136</paragraph><paragraph>and then nearby at:</paragraph><paragraph>Wednesday 4-5pm at Hearst Field Annex B1.</paragraph><paragraph>If you would like to run the coding portion of the lab locally, download this zip file: </paragraph><paragraph>If you would like to run the coding portion of the lab on Google Colab, go to this link: https://tinyurl.com/cs182-dis01-code.</paragraph><paragraph>To save time, it would be useful to get the code set up (including any environments, etc.) on your laptop before the discussion begins. </paragraph><paragraph>For the non-coding part, we will have printed discussion worksheets for you. We will have extras so even if students can't find a seat in the room, we can give you a worksheet so you can get together with other students without a seat and do your own discussion.</paragraph><paragraph>The structure of the discussion in the room will be very interactive. The time will be spent working in small groups on the problems and discussing the concepts, with course staff members circulating among the groups to aid with conceptual understanding, etc. </paragraph><paragraph>There will never be mini-lectures in this course and students are expected to come to discussion wanting and willing to work with others, and fully caught up on lectures and previously due homeworks.</paragraph></document>
document:
Discussion 1 will be held at two times:

Wednesday at 3-4pm in Social Sciences Building 136

and then nearby at:

Wednesday 4-5pm at Hearst Field Annex B1.

If you would like to run the coding portion of the lab locally, download this zip file: 

If you would like to run the coding portion of the lab on Google Colab, go to this link: https://tinyurl.com/cs182-dis01-code.

To save time, it would be useful to get the code set up (including any environments, etc.) on your laptop before the discussion begins. 

For the non-coding part, we will have printed discussion worksheets for you. We will have extras so even if students can't find a seat in the room, we can give you a worksheet so you can get together with other students without a seat and do your own discussion.

The structure of the discussion in the room will be very interactive. The time will be spent working in small groups on the problems and discussing the concepts, with course staff members circulating among the groups to aid with conceptual understanding, etc. 

There will never be mini-lectures in this course and students are expected to come to discussion wanting and willing to work with others, and fully caught up on lectures and previously due homeworks.

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>No PDFs for tablet. We expect people to write on the piece of paper because we expect folks to work in groups. Tablets are less socially interactive. And discussions are socially interactive. </paragraph></document>
comments.document: No PDFs for tablet. We expect people to write on the piece of paper because we expect folks to work in groups. Tablets are less socially interactive. And discussions are socially interactive.

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>How long after the actual discussion will the worksheets be posted on ed?</paragraph></document>
comments.document: How long after the actual discussion will the worksheets be posted on ed?

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>In general, a random amount of time. You should be planning on attending discussion. That's the only reliable way to get the worksheet. Second most reliable is through your study group. Our posting of worksheets is the least reliable.</paragraph><paragraph/></document>
comments.document: In general, a random amount of time. You should be planning on attending discussion. That's the only reliable way to get the worksheet. Second most reliable is through your study group. Our posting of worksheets is the least reliable.
